question: How has the neighborhood where Marcella Ortiz grew up changed over time?
answer: The neighborhood where Marcella Ortiz grew up has become much more expensive over time. It used to be a family-friendly area with many kids, but now it has become more affluent, with luxury cars and a different demographic moving in. Neighbors no longer know each other as they did before.
source_text: I feel like now the house is worth like 2.5 because they extended it out and theres people knocking out the door leaving leaving things on the door if you know asking them if they want to sell and and um so its kind of crazy its one of those its one of those neighborhoods that got really expensive over the time like when we grew up it was just like basketball hoops on the corner of you know the light poles and it was a fam it was so many kids you know there was kids in the neighborhood um and then you know slow slowly but surely As Time passed it was just like you know the Mercedes moved in and the Porsche moved in and um the families kind of were moving out different different demographic was coming in the area and um you know no one really talks to each other back when I grew up everybody all the neighbors knew each other you know

question: How does Marcella Ortiz feel about the construction of new housing projects in San Francisco?
answer: Marcella Ortiz has mixed feelings about new housing projects. While they provide work opportunities, she is concerned that they do not offer enough low-income housing and questions who will actually benefit from these projects.
source_text: is it its a Bittersweet uh feeling for me because when theres projects when theres cranes in the skies that means that I have work and that that that I wont sit at home right but its its bitter for me because I know that all these buildings are going to go up and theres only going to be uh x amount of housing for low income and whats whos really going to move in right what is what what how is it really going to change the city what what is our city gonna you know look like after this project

question: What impact has gentrification had on Marcella Ortiz's community?
answer: Gentrification has led to evictions and displacement in Marcella Ortiz's community, affecting her family and friends. It has also brought about changes in the social dynamics and increased instances of racism.
source_text: being a San Francisco native um and and watching the city change its been rough it has been rough I mean you know um we we see people getting evicted our families are getting evicted my you know my my grandparents were evicted and shortly passed away after once they had to move all the way to Dixon you know my my best friends mom who lived on 19th and Grill she was evicted you know and um and um so many these stories are just its just the displacement it does something it does something to community because its like it really hurts it hurts people

question: How does Marcella Ortiz perceive the changes in San Francisco due to the tech industry?
answer: Marcella Ortiz perceives the tech industry as having increased housing prices and changed the city's demographic, making it less safe due to new residents who frequently call the police.
source_text: I think that one thing that happened with the housing with I feel like its the tech industry the tech industry industry came jacked up all the prices we have a different type of people coming in the city now and its its not really safe because these are the people that are calling the police for every little thing

question: What is Marcella Ortiz's experience living in Hunters Point?
answer: Despite its reputation as a rough neighborhood, Marcella Ortiz finds Hunters Point to be welcoming and community-oriented, with neighbors who know and support each other.
source_text: I live in Hunters Point and they said that this this part of the city is the hardest roughest part of the city this part of the city youll hear gunshots in the night time you know but I can tell you right now that I know my my next door neighbor I talk to him every day my next door neighbor on the left of me I talk to him every day everybody knows the next sober across the street has mental illness the other next door neighbor right here we know his family everybody talks to each other I dont know why is that why is that they um you know uh theres kids running in the street people are helping up each other people are making sure they can get in and out of the parking lot I I dont I dont know why that is they say its the roughest neighborhood in the street the neighborhood in San Francisco but its been the most welcoming to me and its the last gentrified I feel like in San Francisco

question: What is Marcella Ortiz's opinion on the redevelopment of housing projects in San Francisco?
answer: Marcella Ortiz is critical of the redevelopment of housing projects like Sunnydale and Potrero, which she sees as a way to push out the black community. She notes that while vouchers are given, not everyone can return, and this displaces long-standing communities.
source_text: we just redid Sunnydale they knocked down the Sunnydale projects and they gave everybody vouchers but then then then certain people couldnt come back if they had a record of some sort there was there was some language in there that only certain people got vouchers to come back and it was just a way to get the black community and push him out and um I think thats going to continue going on theyre going to continue to say oh were going to redo these housing complexes were going to redo the Potrero theyre doing the patreon right now they knocked down the portrayal housing projects and theyre giving everybody vouchers but theyre pushing a lot of people back and a lot of people are not going to come back they are not coming back

question: What improvements would you like to see in the Hunters Point and Sunnydale areas?
answer: I would like to see more grocery stores that are healthy, like Good Life and Rainbow co-ops, more buses, more schools, and more resources like after-school programs and sports leagues. We have one YMCA, but it would be nice to have more facilities offering extracurricular activities to bring communities together.
source_text: to see more um grocery stores that are healthy like good life rainbow with these co-ops that uh in in um like the Hunters Point um that Hunters Point area the Sunnydale area you know over there where the Geneva Towers were theres theres no theres barely they just put a t over there so even even uh it would be nice to get a bus more buses to go in those areas too um but more buses healthy grocery stores stores that we can actually feed our kids and I I know foods are expensive right now but you know um but it would be nice to see more grocery stores out there and more schools more schools and more resources like after school programs and um soccer leagues and baseball leagues and we have one YMCA thats it we have one facility that offers you know um like um extracurricular activities to our youth in Hunters Point you know so it would be nice to see more resources like that to bring communities together

question: What are your thoughts on the availability of extracurricular activities in Hunters Point?
answer: There are parks, but no clubhouses, after-school programs, or little leagues. The parks are dead because there's no activity. It would be nice to have more extracurricular activities for children, adults, and seniors.
source_text: I would like to see more um extracurricular activities for children um theres Parks but theres theres no clubhouses theres no after school programs theres no little league theres no t-ball theres theres the parks are dead because like wrecking Park they dont they dont have any facility like theres a park but theres you know you go into like the Richmond area and um uh close by there is Portola and they have baseball Little League they have all these different things but if you get into you know Hunters Point like MLK that Park is always dead because theres nothing popping off you know it would be nice to have some extracurricular extracurricular activities for children and also for adults and seniors seniors like to get out too

question: How do you feel about the cultural celebrations in San Francisco?
answer: I have been dancing in Carnaval since I was six years old, and it's a big celebration. These festivals, like the Jazz Festival and Cherry Blossom Festival, make San Francisco unique because they bring together a melting pot of cultures. It's important to preserve these celebrations.
source_text: in the mission I have been dancing in carnival since I was six years old and that is a big celebration that is theres ever since the birth of Carnaval when it was in precedah park theres always been an Ortiz in the parade so I can say that um that that celebration and and that coincides with you know the jazz festival all these festivals the Cherry Blossom Festival you know all these festivals first that make San Francisco unique because it brings all its such a Melting Pot um we have to preserve those celebrations
